A. Robert Kleiner Papers, 1949-1982

Finding aid prepared by:

did.abstract: Grand Rapids, Michigan, attorney and political activist. Subject files relating to his interest in state legislative apportionment, Democratic Party affairs, and Citizen Action, a Grand Rapids, Michigan, non-partisan good government organization; also photographs.
did.physloc: offsite storage; prior notification required for access

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from Mr. Kleiner (donor no. 7061) in April 1984 and April 1985.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., A. Robert Kleiner Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: A. Robert Kleiner was born in Grand Rapids, Michigan, on December 2, 1916. He attended the local public schools and received his A.B. and J.D. degrees from the University of Michigan. After military service and a brief period of employment in Detroit, Kleiner returned to Grand Rapids in 1946 and became a founding partner in the law firm of Kleiner, DeYoung and Fayette. He devoted his practice almost exclusively to labor law.

Among Kleiner's civic and political activities are participation in Citizen Action, the Democratic Party, and the Commission on Legislative Apportionment. In addition, he was a charter member and director of Citizen Action, a Grand Rapids non-partisan organization for good government founded in 1949. He also served as Chairman of the Public Relations Committee in 1950 and Vice-President in 1951.

As a Democratic Party activist, Kleiner has held various offices at the county, congressional district, and state levels of the party organization, and has been a delegate to Democratic Party national conventions. An authority on legislative apportionment, Kleiner was chairman of the Michigan Democratic Party Committee on Apportionment and three-time member of the Michigan Commission on Legislative Apportionment. Twice he served as Co-chairman of the Commission, and twice he was co-author of the apportionment plan which was adopted. The Austin-Kleiner plan was adopted in 1964 and the Hatcher-Kleiner plan in 1972.

scopecontent.p: The Kleiner papers consist of approximately 15.5 feet of materials covering the years of 1949 to 1982. Most of the files are dated in the period of 1961 to 1982, however, and relate to Kleiner's interest in legislative apportionment and Democratic Party affairs. The collection came in two principal accessions, thus some file series are physically separated among different boxes.
The collection has been arranged into five series: Apportionment; Democratic Party; Photographs; Scrapbooks; and Sound Recordings.

controlaccess.head: Subjects - Visual Material:
controlaccess.corpname: Democratic National Convention (1964 : Atlantic City, N.J.)
controlaccess.subject: Politics and government--1961-1970.
Politics and government--1971-1980.

scopecontent.p: The Apportionment series is the largest and most important part of the Kleiner papers. These files have been arranged by decades (1960s, etc.) to distinguish between the apportionment debates and controversies that arise after each decennial census. Apportionment files (except for the 1960s) are further broken down into Michigan Commission on Legislative Apportionment and Democratic Party Apportionment Committee. Kleiner served on both of these bodies.

Legislative Apportionment Commission materials consist of plans and maps, political analyses of plans, litigation files, minutes, correspondence, notes, and papers relating to public hearings and negotiations between Republican and Democratic Commissioners. The files of the Democratic Apportionment Committee consist of similar materials, but these papers were generated for and by the Democratic commissioners and state party leadership. In all cases, notes found here are Mr. Kleiner's handwritten notes on meetings, conferences, and telephone calls.

For papers relating to apportionment in the 1960s the researcher should consult the Wilber M. Brucker collection, also available at the Bentley Library, which contain plans, minutes, and litigation proceedings. The Kleiner papers supplement, but do not duplicate, what is in the Brucker collection.

The apportionment papers of the 1980s have major differences from the 1960s and 1970s. Although there are fewer newspaper clippings, the minutes of Commission meetings are more extensive, consisting of both summary minutes and verbatim minutes with exhibits. Computers were used in the 1980s, and analyses of the plans are in the form of computer print outs. These printouts contain extensive political and demographic data for the proposed districts.

scopecontent.p: The Democratic Party series has been arranged by level of activity: Grand Rapids, Kent County, Fifth Congressional District, State, and National. At the city level there is an undated report on municipal government. County level papers (1969-1979), arranged chronologically, consist of correspondence, minutes of the Kent County Democratic Committee and Executive Committee, and county convention materials. District level papers (1968-1976) consist of chronologically arranged folders containing correspondence, notes on committee meetings, and materials relating to fund raising dinners. There are also papers relating to delegate selection for national conventions (1976-1980) and election analyses by George Weaver (1973-1974).

For the state level, there are chronological files of correspondence and minutes for the State Central Committee (1965-1981), and papers relating to state conventions (1968-1979). Additionally, there are topical files relating to apportionment, con-con, the Rules and Political Reform Committee, judicial nominations, a party think tank, and a 1978 White House briefing for the Democratic State Party leadership. National Convention files (1964-1980) contain correspondence, caucus minutes, and papers relating to the Michigan Delegation.

did.unittitle: Grand Rapids Municipal Government in Grand Rapids: A Plan for Action (undated report of Local Government Study Committee)
United States District Court (Western Michigan District) 1961
White House Briefing for Michigan Leadership 1978

scopecontent.p: Photos of the members of the Michigan Commission on Legislative Apportionment; also photos of delegates taken on the floor of the 1964 Democratic National Convention.
The Scrapbook series consists of four volumes dated May 1949 -January 1950 and includes clippings about Citizen Action.

The Sound Recordings Series includes cassettes and reel-to-reel tapes from 1970 and 1980 apportionment meetings and public hearings, 1963 Con-Con debates, and miscellaneous newscasts, interviews and press conferences relating to Citizen Action, Grand Rapids, and President Gerald R. Ford.
